Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 12:23PM Hopbird wrote: I found out I had A brain met about a year ago, but a pretty big one cause nobody was looking for it.  It continues to cause some confusion, but the two little spots they found after were gone with radiation in November and nothing else has shown up.  My Onc said she had known people who had them once or twice, easily stopped with radiation, and nothing else.  There's a website about BrainMets that has some good info, and there are people that have lived 10+ year with them.  And I figure that was people that were diagnosed 10 years ago, so there's even more hope now.  Right now you would not know I have ever had cancer of any sort and certainly not brain mets.  I am 51, live a normal life, work part time as I was before, run around with my children, etc.  I just graduated the second one from high school and he leaves for college in a few weeks.  With his senior year and my younger child running the show in eighth grade, it was a great year to have, and I'm looking forward to more.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 12:31PM - edited Nov 3, 2009 12:37PM by Hopbird Portergirl, I'm going to answer your post here.  LGFB is a Look Good Feel Better class offered by the American Cancer Society.  It's free, you just need to find a location and sign up.  They give you new makeup (nice stuff, too) and talk to you about the whole hair loss thing as well as hair covering options.  They talk to you about how to care for your skin and do your makeup since that changes a bit with chemo and becomes important if you are trying to look healthy and especially if you aren't wearing wigs. I took mine at Georgia Cancer Specialists, even though I'm not having treatment there.  The girl that came (her name is Jamie) works in a salon in downtown Alpharetta called Borellis (right at Old Milton) and she has a little room with all of her products for cancer patients.  She's very helpful and will order wigs and all, but I already had a wig and went in there to get a few hair coverings.  She will close the door and work with you to try different options and doesn't make you feel pressured...she just wants you to see choices.  I'd just call and make sure she will be there and then go in.  She was great! Brenda, I hate that your port access hurt so much.  Part of that may have been the newness of the port and the soreness of the area.  I've had mine accessed 7 times now, and I've found that some are absolutely painless and some hurt a little, and I can't tell why it is different.  That cream sounds like a good option.  Of course, you can always use my favorite trick any time a needle comes at me.  I don't look!  I tell them if I don't look I can pretend it isn't happening!  OH, and besides our diagnosis dates we have another thing in common.  I have three sons as well.  The oldest left for college right before I turned the phone on and had a message from my oncologist.....then I cried twice as hard.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 03:30PM Hopbird wrote: Hi Ladies... I just wanted to pop by and see how Brenda did......sounds like everything went well....at least on the chemo scale!  Congrats on having it and the terrors over with! CCNani, I just want to comment on your Her2+ status.  While at one point, Her2+ cancer was not a good thing, that has been offset by the success of Herceptin.  I encourage you to go read the Her2+ thread.  It means we have to take the stinking drug for a year, but it has been very exciting in the field and has made being Her2+ NOT not necessarily a bad thing any more!   I know you may read things that say so, but realize that Herceptin has only been used for early stage cancer for a very short time, and they stopped some trials that would have given some good data early because they felt it wasn't right to deprive some participants of it.  BTW, my doctor also wanted to shy away from AC because of the cardiac issue in combination with the Herceptin.  One or the other, but not both! Coolbreeze, I also know how you feel about the one year thing........yep, me too!  Although I think after my chemo is over and I'm down to just Herceptin every few weeks it will feel like a picnic.  My youngest just turned 13 a week ago.  Oddly, he handles this whole thing better than anyone.  Kids don't have the same perception of "cancer" that we grew up with.  Just let him know you'll have days you don't feel well, but there will be others when you feel just fine, and take advantage of those for him.  Good luck to all of those that are starting soon!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 02:39PM Hopbird wrote: Portergirl...seems they could have saved that news for just a few hours.  I'm at Emory, not Piedmont.  I won't go into my history, I've gone on a bumpy road, but will say that I also thought it was just DCIS and then found I had a microinvasion.  Her2 cancer is aggressive, but getting Herceptin offsets that.  And they find that chemo makes the Herceptin work better.  You are going to be great, this is just insurance that a very tiny but aggressive cancer doesn't get a chance to build up. Glad you got in the class.  I thought it was helpful, and the freebies were good.  I'm not doing TCH, although it was my other option and I thought hard about it.  Emory is trying a new Protocol that I'm doing.  They didn't really recommend it over the TCH other than that the version of Taxol I'm taking might be (and they said MIGHT) a little easier to tolerate than some other protocols.  The TCH we talked about was every three weeks for 18 weeks also with weekly Herceptin, then Herceptin every three weeks...same as you are doing.  The Herceptin alone doesn't bother me at all, other than a little stomach stuff that night....just a few belches and maybe a quick trip to the bathroom.  By the next day I'm up and running, and that whole week life is good.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 02:40PM - edited Oct 18, 2009 02:43PM by Hopbird I'm currently taking Abraxane instead of Taxol.  I go for my third tomorrow...they've been every other week, dose dense.  The mixing does take forever...I guess that's the bad news.  The good news is that it takes awhile because it isn't dissolved in solvents that cause their own side effects.  My infusion is for 30 minutes.  I haven't needed steroids.  I haven't had any nerve pain...knocking wood.  I did lose my hair about a week ago.  I get compazine before the infusion and have had no nausea.  I have had a little indigestion...but I liken it to the results of eating a greasy cheeseburger...without any of the pleasure!  I do get Neulasta a day after the infusion to build up white cells.   I don't know if a weekly dose would require it or not. That causes some bone/joint pain.  It is tolerable, and I am allowed some OTC pain killers at the time.  That lasts 2 - 3 days, and for me is worst in the evening.  Hope it goes well for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 04:27PM Hopbird wrote: Hi everyone....... I'm new around here, but started my chemo September 21.  I'm doing a non-standard regimen, chemo every two weeks for four cycles, herceptin every week, then 12 weeks chemo along with herceptin.  I wanted to post because I learned something interesting about self-injecting with Neulasta, at least in my situation.  If I get the injections at the medical facility the costs are all covered under my medical insurance.  If I pick it up at a pharmacy and self-inject or have someone do it for me, the cost is covered under my prescription plan...........NOT good, coverage is not nearly as good.  It is something that would be good for others to check before they decide to take that route. Also, whoever asked about bone pain from Neulasta.....I had only a little, mostly in the evening, for some reason.  It started the evening AFTER the shot was given, went away the next morning, was back the next evening, that was about it.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 05:58AM - edited Oct 2, 2009 06:09AM by Hopbird Hi Unclezwifeonty.. Your pharmacy situation is better than mine.......it's $100 at the pharmacy for me.  We still thought about doing it rather than driving into town, but since I have three more....dunno.  Thanks to diagnostic procedures I've maxxed my out of pocket for the year on my medical so I won't pay anything there.....  Right now I'm looking at having a local hospital (affiliated on paper with the one that I'm seeing in town) administer the shot.  Then I get the best of both worlds.  I don't know that it will happen, though.  Red tape being what it is.......... And I'm not doing the A/C - T.  My doctor didn't even like that option because of the possibility of heart toxicity.  I have borderline BP and all, increases my risk with the Herceptin.  My regimen is part of a study..drugs that have worked well against advanced disease with Herceptin, they're looking at using them more for early disease.  They'll scan me again at 8 weeks and see if it seems to be having an effect.  If not, we will have to decide whether to continue or swtich to TCH.   Why did I go this route?  They've had good results with patients so far, and the combination is supposed to be a bit less toxic and easier to tolerate.  I'm fine with that, so long as they can make sure it is doing its job.  My first round was relatively easy to tolerate.  Second round next Monday......we'll see. I should maybe explain that my first diagnosis was May 2008.  I had surgery (mastectomy, tram reconstruction) but no chemo at the time.  All doctors and I thought that was the best decision based upon the fact that I had almost all DCIS, one microinvasion.  Then, in August I found out that I had beat the odds (lucky me :( ) and although I had been node negative at the time of my surgery I now have a node that has cancer in it.  That's why we're doing chemo.  They did a scan to be sure I had no mets, and that came back fine.  When they re-scan they want to see the node smaller and less active.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 09:51PM - edited Oct 11, 2009 10:36PM by Hopbird Good luck tomorrow Uncleswifeonty.  I think you started a week after me.  I have a friend who did A/C - T.  She said her head hair started coming out at about 17 days.  While I'm on a Taxol relative, day 17 was memorable for my head hair as well.  I was trying to get ready for work and every time I would reach up and try to fix a place or brush something, half of that hair would come out in my hand.  I told my co-worker I nearly just stuck my wig on over my hair and went!  That was Thursday.  Yesterday I had my hair trimmed uber-short by a friend.  I can wear my caps and all comfortably, wore my wig to church, but still have a little hair here around the house.  But I'm shedding like crazy.  Wasn't ready to buzz it all off, but I"m second-guessing myself every time I brush the stray hairs off of me.  While everyone is different, you definitely may want to make sure you are ready.  It hasn't been as traumatic as I thought it might, I cried when I watched Renee's video, then I was done.  My family has been great.  I feel a little self-conscious wearing wigs and hats, but I'm sure I'll get used to it.  Haven't tried the scarf thing in public yet.  Won't go out in my uber-short hair.........too many "wide parts" in the style!  :)  Come to think of it, I was standing behind some 40 something dads who were sitting at my son's game and thinking that my hair is about as thin as theirs! Good luck again tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 03:02PM Hopbird wrote: I can't help you guys taking taxol completely, because I am on Abraxane, alike but different.  I can say that it has been pretty tolerable.  It did take my hair, I have a day of hangover afterward, and then several days of achiness either due to it or the neulasta shot I get the next day.  If I had to work during both I could...glad I don't, though.  I go in on Thursdays after having chemo Monday.  It has affected my liver enzymes, but my other numbers have stayed good through three rounds.  I haven't had any mouth sores...a little mung mouth.  My digestive system is definitely not fully on, I try to use wipes to keep the nethers from getting irritated.  Also main possibility is nerve pain in feet and hands.  Haven't had that either, knock on wood.  Hopefully you guys' experience will be comparable.

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 03:17PM Hopbird wrote: Mrs. B...I'm a sort of recurrence as well.  I decided to just look at things as if God gave me some time off in the middle of treatment.  My mastectomy was just over a year ago.  Nodes were negative and tumor was not measurable...the reason I had mastectomy was simply that I had a lot of DCIS and they wouldn't have been able to give good cosmetic result with lumpectomy.  The doctors told me my odds of recurrence were slim and we all decided chemo was just as risky.  I'm HER + but ER and PR - so no Tamoxifen.  Then a year later they did MRI checking my other side and found an inflamed node on my mastectomy side.  Same characteristics as my first, so recurrence of first cancer.  So now I'm getting the full arsenal.  My scans also came back negative.  The good thing about me not doing the chemo a year ago is that I developed complications about 8 weeks after surgery, probably would have started chemo by that time.  Can't imagine how that would have gone, since it took four rounds of antibiotics to be rid of the thing WITHOUT a compromised immune system!! Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 09:02AM - edited Nov 24, 2009 09:03AM by Hopbird Onty, that's a shame about your study....even though Taxol and Abraxane are the same drug, I guess it has to be exact.  I think you'll find Abraxane tolerable, especially after the first day or two.  I had four doses, two weeks apart.  I never got neuropathy, but another lady I met doing my same regimen did.  I did have body aches, but I got Neulasta injections so I don't know if they were from the Abraxane or the Neulasta....my guess is the latter.  I wonder if you'll get that.  My Abraxane was dose dense...maybe that matters?   Both me and the other woman I met on the same regimen said the body aches were worst after the first Tx...for whatever reason. Jayne, I had similar complications after my surgery...although I never needed hospitalized.  It's so wonderful how people will step up for us, isn't it?  I wasn't on chemo when mine happened, but it started several weeks (6 to 8) after surgery.  I kept having fluid, though, that my PS drained with a syringe.  Finally they scheduled me to have a drain put back in, but then by the time they got me in it had gone down and they couldn't find a big enough area to install the drain.  I was on antibiotics for a month....it was not fun, but I got through it.  Hang in there! Anita, glad you handled your Taxol OK.  My worst SE (and I never felt this one) was that my liver enzymes climbed.  They sonogrammed my liver and it was fine.  Now that I've gotten off of the Abraxane they have lowered...not to normal yet, but they're heading the right way!

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 08:08PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 08:11PM by Hopbird Onty, I still haven't had a double.  I wasn't ready to give up on my "other".  They found the lymph node inflamed on my mastectomy side....the one that had tested negative.  Either it was positive and the sampling didn't find it or some cancerous cells found their way there.  There is a low percentage chance of this happening with sentinel node...I just beat the odds.....and not in a good way. It was explained to me that just because you've had BC doesn't mean your risk of getting it in the other breast is that much higher.  I decided to hang on to what I had, and I guess time will tell if that is the right decision.  Now if I thought I had developed a SECOND cancer I think I'd be feeling like I wanted to remove about anything I could that could possibly develop into cancer. And MrsB you're exactly right.  I think I had to come to terms shortly after diagnosis with the fact that I don't have any control or choice about how this all works out.  Once you accept that, you do all you can and live with what comes next.  I much prefer being in control.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 05:12PM - edited Feb 11, 2010 05:17PM by Hopbird Anita...the doctors check the nodes manually as part of the followup, but with scar tissue and stuff hadn't felt anything yet.  The positive node got found because of an MRI being done to make sure my cancer-free side was still cancer free.  Funny thing about MRIs, they look at both sides.  They noticed the node, did a sonogram to make sure it was really worth looking into, then did a biopsy and found cancer, some properties as the one they had removed previously.  My surgeon thinks I had a false negative.....rare, especially at my place, but it can happen.  My medical oncologist says we don't really know, could just be that the cells got there later.  The tissue under the arm is part of your breast tissue and my disease was multifocal so I guess there could have been more there.  Who knows?  Just glad they found it before it went anywhere else.  (Yes, they did a scan to check that.) I'm proud of your new focus on healthy living......you know it has to help....... Lisa, that's a LOTTTTT of pills!  Better to think one day at a time!

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 02:34PM - edited Apr 22, 2011 02:36PM by Hopbird I have two thoughts on this...first, when I had a recurrence in my nodes, my older and wiser doctor said NOT to keep secrets because that's telling your kids that its OK for your family to do.  So basically, once we had a plan of how to handle it (because we couldn't answer their questions until then) we just told them. My stage IV diagnosis came in the way of brain surgery, so there was no secret.  I haven't dwelt on what is to come because right now I'm fine.  The people around me know it has spread...I can't worry about what they think that means.  I don't really know what any of it means, I am going to keep my thoughts on the fact that I'll figure it out later...although I have started doing the things that are important...no sense putting it off!  :)  I figure it will sink in over time, and everyone knows what the possibilities are.  And one thing that has helped me was the realization that whether kids are 4 or 40, most don't want anything bad to happen to mom, but eventually it does.  Its never going to be easy for them.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 11:55AM Hopbird wrote: Janis...what a nice post.  I hope you know you're important and inspirational to people too.  Nobody can understand what Metastatic people go through...it was once described to me as lonely...and I think that's a good description.  Even though among us there are different cases, ages, etc.  But we do have a shared experience that most thank goodness won't ever be able to understand.  Why were we the unlucky ones?  Isn't that the million dollar question.  I've heard so many stories and they're all different.  Bottom line is people still don't know what causes the disease in the first place and with some why it spreads.  All we can control is what we can...and it's nice to have others that get it while we do.

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 06:20PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 06:23PM by Hopbird I'm glad you talked to your doctor.  I'll echo what the others said...the surgery you had was extremely rough.  I found recovery from it MUCH more debilitating than the chemo has been.  I'm just over a month into chemo and have been to my kids games, driven carpool, and kept up with normal life MOST days.  On my "hangover" days I take it easy, but there are a lot of good days mixed in. Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 03:36PM Hopbird wrote: On the questions...it's a long story.  I initially had a traditional surgery as my met was pretty big and had been growing undetected then was found in an emergency, and follow-up radiation.  The first SRS was for a smaller tumor found right after that which totally went away after SRS.  That was about 1 1/2 years ago.  The tumor that was surgically worked on started re-growing.  I had ANOTHER surgery, but they didn't get it all.  I had SRS again in November on the small area the surgeon missed.  It seems to be working, but it is too soon to tell about radiation damage...and the radiation guy does worry about that!  I was losing functionality to the disease, so the risk doesn't seem as bad as the alternative.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 07:47AM Hopbird wrote: Sorry about you joining the club. What I have decided for me is that there's no point trying to figure out what a stage means, because its different for everyone.  I think we try to keep going, whether its six months or 20 years, and just deal with the chips as they fall, figuring out the next thing to do then.  I'm a little more organized than I might have been, probably a little more tired depending on the meds, and I say little things to prepare my kids that they might not have to deal with old/senile me.  We don't even know the long term effects of some of the meds we're taking because they're too new!  Other than that, I live with the words I'm fine for now!  And I, more than a lot, realize none of us really knows how much time we have.
